title: 111_s3810
content: The Act may be cited as the "Gulf Security and Iran Sanctions Enforcement Act" and includes a restriction on participation in offshore oil and gas leasing. The "Gulf Security and Iran Sanctions Enforcement Act" mandates that leases for drilling on the Outer Continental Shelf require annual certification that the lessee does not engage in activities sanctionable under the Iran Sanctions Act. Failure to certify or providing false information can result in lease cancellation. The Secretary may cancel a lease if the lessee fails to make a required certification or provides false information. The Secretary of the Interior must include a disclosure requirement in leases authorizing drilling on the Outer Continental Shelf, requiring disclosure of any involvement in energy-related ventures outside Iran. The Secretary can cancel a lease if the lessee fails to disclose involvement in blocked entities or provides false information as per Executive Orders and regulations. The Secretary has the authority to cancel a lease if the lessee fails to disclose involvement with blocked entities or provides false information, as outlined in regulations. The Secretary, in consultation with other government officials, will cancel the lease if false disclosure is made. The Secretary of the Interior may waive this requirement on a case-by-case basis if it is deemed in the national interest, with reporting requirements to Congress. The Secretary of the Interior has the authority to cancel a lease if false information is provided or involvement with blocked entities is not disclosed. Waivers can be granted on a case-by-case basis if it is in the national interest, with reporting requirements to Congress. The appropriate congressional committees must be promptly informed of any lease cancellations, with specific committees identified for notification. The term "person" is defined in the Iran Sanctions Act of 1996. Congressional committees involved in lease cancellations include the Committee on Natural Resources, Committee on Foreign Affairs, Committee on Energy and Natural Resources, and Committee on Foreign Relations. The Act will end 30 days after Iran stops supporting terrorism, pursuing weapons of mass destruction, and no longer poses a threat to US national security.
